user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_mkdir:
```c
int lfs_mkdir(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mkdir(%p, \"%s\")", (void*)lfs, path);

    err = lfs_mkdir_(lfs, path);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mkdir -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_mkdir:
static int lfs_mkdir_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path) {
    // deorphan if we haven't yet, needed at most once after poweron
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    struct lfs_mlist cwd;
    cwd.next = lfs->mlist;
    uint16_t id;
    err = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd.m, &path, &id);
    if (!(err == LFS_ERR_NOENT && lfs_path_islast(path))) {
        return (err < 0) ? err : LFS_ERR_EXIST;
    }

    // check that name fits
    lfs_size_t nlen = lfs_path_namelen(path);
    if (nlen > lfs->name_max) {
        return LFS_ERR_NAMETOOLONG;
    }

    // build up new directory
    lfs_alloc_ckpoint(lfs);
    lfs_mdir_t dir;
    err = lfs_dir_alloc(lfs, &dir);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // find end of list
    lfs_mdir_t pred = cwd.m;
    while (pred.split) {
        err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &pred, pred.tail);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    // setup dir
    lfs_pair_tole32(pred.tail);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &dir, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_SOFTTAIL, 0x3ff, 8), pred.tail}));
    lfs_pair_fromle32(pred.tail);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // current block not end of list?
    if (cwd.m.split) {
        // update tails, this creates a desync
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, +1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        // it's possible our predecessor has to be relocated, and if
        // our parent is our predecessor's predecessor, this could have
        // caused our parent to go out of date, fortunately we can hook
        // ourselves into littlefs to catch this
        cwd.type = 0;
        cwd.id = 0;
        lfs->mlist = &cwd;

        lfs_pair_tole32(dir.pair);
        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &pred, LFS_MKATTRS(
                {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_SOFTTAIL, 0x3ff, 8), dir.pair}));
        lfs_pair_fromle32(dir.pair);
        if (err) {
            lfs->mlist = cwd.next;
            return err;
        }

        lfs->mlist = cwd.next;
        err = lfs_fs_preporphans(lfs, -1);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    // now insert into our parent block
    lfs_pair_tole32(dir.pair);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd.m, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_CREATE, id, 0), NULL},
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_DIR, id, nlen), path},
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_DIRSTRUCT, id, 8), dir.pair},
            {LFS_MKTAG_IF(!cwd.m.split,
                LFS_TYPE_SOFTTAIL, 0x3ff, 8), dir.pair}));
    lfs_pair_fromle32(dir.pair);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    return 0;
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No other code fragments modify the value of any function parameter. The parameter 'lfs' is only dereferenced and its pointed-to objects/members are modified (which is allowed by the rule). Other uses of 'path' are passed by value (e.g., to lfs_path_islast, lfs_path_namelen, lfs_dir_commit) and do not reassign the parameter itself. Macros LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK/LFS_TRACE do not assign to the function parameters. Therefore the call passing &path is the sole location that allows modification of the parameter variable and should be investigated.
